title: VC Daily: How Should Investors Respond to Facebook's Metaverse Bet?
text:
Please email responses to marc.vartabedian@wsj.com.

And now on to the news...

Top News

Strategy shift. New Enterprise Associates is raising a total of about $7 billion for a pair of funds, one for early-stage startup deals and another for later-stage rounds, according to people familiar with the situation, WSJ Pro's Yuliya Chernova and Preeti Singh report. The effort represents a change to NEA's longtime strategy of investing out of a single multistage fund.

The firm is looking to raise just under $3 billion for its early-stage strategy, New Enterprise Associates 18 LP, and about $4 billion for NEA 18 Venture Growth Equity LP, the people said. This represents a large step up from its previous fundraising, which totaled $3.6 billion in early 2020 for its 17th main fund.

NEA's decision to create separate funds for investments by stage reflects what's happening in the venture market broadly. "A lot of firms have been raising multiple funds delineated by stage, but also sometimes by sector or geography as well," said Aakar Vachhani, a partner at Fairview Capital, speaking generally about the venture market.

$100 Million

Amount raised by Lovevery in its latest funding round, valuing the trendy subscription toy company at more than $800 million. (WSJ)

Satellite Maker Terran Orbital Strikes $1.58 Billion SPAC Deal

Satellite maker Terran Orbital Corp. is merging with a special-purpose acquisition company to go public at a $1.58 billion valuation, the companies said, the latest in a string of space-related companies to list through a SPAC, The Wall Street Journal's Ben Dummett reports. Florida-based Terran designs and builds satellites for customers including the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the U.S. Defense Department and EchoStar Corp., a provider of satellite and internet communication services. Terran is developing its own constellation of low-Earth-orbit satellites, with plans to launch next year, and is targeting customers such as shippers that need to track their vessels and governments monitoring conflict zones. Terran, founded in 2013, is merging with Tailwind Two Acquisition Corp., a SPAC listed on the New York Stock Exchange and led by Casper Sleep Inc. Chief Executive Philip Krim.

Global Regulators Back Tougher Rules Targeting Crypto Crime

Cryptocurrency firms could be forced to take greater steps to combat money laundering under new guidelines released on Thursday by the Financial Action Task Force, an international body that coordinates government policy on illicit finance, Alexander Osipovich reports for the Journal. The task force called on governments to broaden regulatory oversight of crypto firms and force more of them to take measures such as checking the identities of their customers and reporting suspicious transactions to regulators. The FATF's guidelines don't have the force of law, and would need to be implemented by national regulators in each country. Still, the Paris-based group is influential in setting standards for government policies against money laundering and financing of terrorism, and its guidelines could shape new crypto regulations around the world.

"It would be inappropriate for anything like these non-specific and confusing standards to replace the current law and regulations we have on the books here in the U.S."

— Peter Van Valkenburgh, research director at crypto advocacy group Coin Center, wrote in a blog post Thursday about the FATF guidelines.

Experience Management Forum

If you are interested in fintech and customer experience, come along to the WSJ Experience Management Forum on Nov. 1. Speakers include executives from two venture-backed companies: Ronald Oliveira, U.S. chief executive of Revolut, and David Sandstrom, chief marketing officer of Klarna. Register here using the code EXPREPORT.

Industry News

Funds

Fifty Years raised $90 million for its third fund to continue making pre-seed and seed investments in deep tech startups across North America and Europe. Founders of unicorn tech companies including Skype, Spotify, GitHub, Klarna, Dropbox, Snowflake and Zendesk are among the fund's limited partners. The San Francisco firm collected $50 million for its preceding fund in 2019.

Omnichannel distribution, data and media company Accelerate360 launched a strategic investment arm, NextUp360 Ventures, to focus on consumer-packaged goods and related services. Portfolio companies include specialty wine and craft spirits marketplace Grapestars and wellness regimen provider Gryph & IvyRose.

People

Andreessen Horowitz said Jai Ramaswamy will join the firm's crypto team as chief regulatory officer. He was also recently added to the board of directors of the Celo Foundation.

Michelle Delcambre joined Felicis Ventures as operating partner. She was previously head of global people operations at Stripe, and led talent acquisition at Databricks and Okta.

Bitpanda appointed Joshua Barraclough as chief executive of Bitpanda Pro, its digital asset exchange. He was previously co-head of digital innovation at J.P. Morgan. Vienna-based Bitpanda recently raised $263 million in Series C funding led by Valar Ventures at a $4.1 billion valuation.

Joywell Foods, a protein-based sweetener developer, named Ali Wing as chief executive. She was most recently chief consumer officer at Bright Health. Davis, Calif.-based Joywell is backed by investors including Evolv Ventures, Khosla Ventures and SOSV.

Exits

AgomAb Therapeutics NV, a Belgian developer of therapies for structural tissue repair and functional organ recovery, agreed to acquire Spain-based Origo Biopharma SL, which is developing drug candidates for the treatment of fibrosis-related disorders. Terms weren't disclosed. In March, AgomAb said it raised a $74 million Series B round from Redmile Group, Advent France Biotechnology, Andera Partners, Boehringer Ingelheim Venture Fund and others. Asabys Partners led Origo Biopharma's €2.3 million seed round last year.

VidMob Inc., a provider of tools and services for marketers to create and improve their digital advertising, agreed to purchase fellow adtech company Chiligum for an undisclosed amount. New York-based VidMob's ventures backers include Drive by DraftKings, Prefix Capital, BuildGroup, Interlock Partners and Macanta Investments.

New Money

ClickUp, a San Diego-based workplace productivity platform, raised $400 million in Series C funding, giving the company a valuation of $4 billion. Andreessen Horowitz and Tiger Global Management co-led the round, which included contributions from Lightspeed Venture Partners and Meritech Capital Partners.

ACKO, an Indian digital insurance provider, collected $255 million in Series D funding, bringing the company's valuation up to $1.1 billion. Lead investors General Atlantic and Multiples Private Equity were joined by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board, Lightspeed Venture Partners, Intact Ventures and Munich Re Ventures in the round.

Alchemy, a San Francisco-based blockchain developer platform, fetched $250 million in Series C funding led by Andreessen Horowitz, valuing the company at $3.5 billion. Additional new investors Lightspeed Venture Partners and Redpoint Ventures also contributed to the round, alongside previous backers Coatue Management, Addition, DFJ Growth and Pantera Capital.

ClickHouse Inc., a San Francisco- and Amsterdam-based creator of an online analytical processing database management system, landed $250 million in Series B funding at a $2 billion valuation. Coatue Management and Altimeter Capital led the investment, which included support from Index Ventures, Benchmark, Lightspeed Venture Partners, Redpoint Ventures and others.

Dragos Inc., a Hanover, Md.-based industrial cybersecurity startup, grabbed $200 million in Series D financing at a valuation of $1.7 billion. Koch Disruptive Technologies and funds and accounts managed by BlackRock led the investment, which included participation from Emerson, Hewlett Packard Enterprise, AllegisCyber, Canaan Partners, DataTribe, Energy Impact Partners, National Grid Partners, Global Reserve Group, Schweitzer Engineering Laboratories and Rockwell Automation.

Ontra, a San Francisco-based contract automation and intelligence startup formerly known as InCloudCounsel, secured $200 million in Series B financing. Blackstone Growth led the round, which included additional support from Battery Ventures. Paul Morrissey, a managing director at Blackstone, joined the company's board.

Vastu Housing Finance Corporation Ltd., an Indian affordable housing finance company, nabbed a $200 million investment. Lead investors Norwest Venture Partners and Creation Investments Capital Management were joined by IIFL Finance in the round.

Yugabyte Inc., a Sunnyvale, Calif.-based open source distributed SQL database startup, closed a $188 million oversubscribed Series C round led by Sapphire Ventures, valuing the company at more than $1.3 billion. New investors Alkeon Capital, Meritech Capital and Wells Fargo Strategic Capital also participated in the funding, along with existing backers Lightspeed Venture Partners, 8VC, Dell Technologies Capital, Wipro Ventures and others. Sapphire President Jai Das will join Yugabyte's board.

Rad Power Bikes, a Seattle-based e-bike company, picked up a $154 million investment. Fidelity Management & Research Co. led the round, which saw participation from funds and accounts advised by T. Rowe Price Associates Inc., Counterpoint Global, Vulcan Capital, Durable Capital Partners and The Rise Fund.

DeHaat, which offers agricultural services to farmers in India, scored $115 million in Series D funding. Sofina and Lightrock India led the round, which included participation from Temasek Holdings, Prosus, RTP Global, Sequoia Capital India and FMO.

Persefoni, a Tempe, Ariz.-based climate management and accounting platform, secured $101 million in Series B financing. Led by Prelude Ventures and TPG Rise Climate, the round included contributions from Clearvision Ventures, Parkway Ventures, Bain & Co., Électricité de France, Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp., The Ferrante Group, Alumni Ventures Group, New Valley Ventures, NGP Energy Technology Partners and Sallyport Investments. Prelude Ventures' Victoria Beasley and TPG Rise Climate's Steve Ellis joined Persefoni's board.

N!CK'S, a healthy snacks and ice cream brand based in Sweden, raised $100 million in Series C funding led by Kinnevik, Ambrosia Investments and Temasek Holdings.

Tech News

Square Inc.'s CFO talks bitcoin, Afterpay and Cash App

Hamilton Lane backs fintech company Tifin

Northwell teams with Aegis Ventures to foster AI-driven healthcare startups
